citation.article-title: Brachymonas denitrificans gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic chemoorganotrophic bacterium which contains rhodoquinones, and evolutionary retionships of rhodoquinone producers to bacterial species with various quinone classes.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Brachymonas (Bra.chy.monas. Gr. adj. brachy short; Gr. n. monas, a unit, monad; M.L. fem. n. Brachymonas, a small short unit)
Cells are nonsporeforming nonmotile coccobacilli or short rods measuring 0.6 to 1.0 μm wide and 1.2 to 2.0 μm long.
Aerobic chemoorganotroph having a strictly respiratory type of metabolism with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Anaerobic growth with nitrate as the terminal acceptor is also possible; denitrification positive.
Good growth occurs in ordinary nutrient media containing peptone or in mineral media supplemented with simple organic compounds as carbon and energy sources.
Amylase, protease, and lipase are absent.
No acid is produced from sugars including glucose.
Major fatty acid components are C16:1 and C16:0.
Major quinones are Q-8 and RQ-8.
Mol% G+C of DNA is from 63 to 65.
Phylogenetic position is in the beta subclass of the Proteobacteria, possibly a member of the family Comamonadaceae.
The type species is Brachymonas denitrificans.
